Name: Gaider's Mourn
Description:
The Mourn is a stalagmite vast as a crag, and its foot has no safe harbours. The corsair's citadel nestles halfway up. An intricate system of winches takes the strain... and your ship rises slowly from the zee. Her hull creaks in protest. Grizzled zailors groan and cling to stanchions.

Higher, higher. Now the Unterzee shimmers like glass below. Children clambering in crevices cheer and wave alarmingly. The winch-motor slows, and you hang in a cradle next to a red-bowed pirate cutter.

ChildBranches.Name: Explore the Mourn
ChildBranches.Description: There's a surprising quantity of actual landscape on the Mourn. It's vertical, admittedly, but once you find the beast-paths and urchin-roads, you can traverse it as you would a rocky moor, with an additional throatful of lurching terror.

ChildBranches.Name: Explore the Mourn
ChildBranches.Description: There's a surprising quantity of actual landscape on the Mourn. It's vertical, admittedly, but once you find the beast-paths and urchin-roads, you can traverse it as you would a rocky moor, with an additional throatful of lurching terror.

ChildBranches.Description: There's a surprising quantity of actual landscape on the Mourn. It's vertical, admittedly, but once you find the beast-paths and urchin-roads, you can traverse it as you would a rocky moor, with an additional throatful of lurching terror.

DefaultEvent.Name: Cold shoulders at the Arrant Limpet
DefaultEvent.Description: Conversation quietens as the drinkers look round. You've been here too long, and you're attracting the wrong kind of attention. Time to move on.

ChildBranches.Name: Another afternoon at the Arrant Limpet
ChildBranches.Description: A drinking-den by the dock-cradles is a good place for your crew to find companionship and let off steam... but although Gaider's Mourn is a free port, the corsairs prefer their own, and look askance at 'respectable' Londoners.

DefaultEvent.Name: A grin
DefaultEvent.Description:
"Ye're a generous soul. Ye'll have yer reward the other side of the River, one day. And here's a little reward for now. Good zailing to ye!"

The report is barely legible. Perhaps that's part of the code. The Admiralty will know.

ChildBranches.Name: Pay the Loitering Docker for his Strategic Information
ChildBranches.Description: "Admiralty sent you? Price has gone up. It's not safe here. Ye'll pay the difference, won't ye?"

DefaultEvent.Name: A shrug
DefaultEvent.Description:
"Ye can't blame me for tryin'. I wants to get home. Sick of this place. London, eh? How is the old monster? - wait, they'll see. Here's yer report. I'm off!"

The report is barely legible. Perhaps that's part of the code. The Admiralty will know.

ChildBranches.Name: Refuse to pay for the information
ChildBranches.Description: "Ye're a rough cove. Come on. This is me living and me life -"

DefaultEvent.Name: A sigh of relief
DefaultEvent.Description: "Oh, oh, I feel it lifting. It's gone from me! You never saw me." [Return to the Blind Bruiser in London. Don't lose your cargo.]

ChildBranches.Name: A Shivering Corsair with a package
ChildBranches.Description: "Oh, God, they're cold. Take them from me. Take them. Where's my money? Don't you cheat me. Take them, but I want my money."

DefaultEvent.Name: A wild seed
DefaultEvent.Description: Off it goes, into the teeming, stinking hollows of the stalagmite. Probably it'll just end up in a pirate's pot. Probably.

ChildBranches.Name: Introduce blemmigans to the Mourn
ChildBranches.Description: So many nooks, so many crannies, so many villains. It seems only appropriate.

DefaultEvent.Name: Business concluded
DefaultEvent.Description:
At the winch-head, a deferential fellow in fustian waits. He bows to the Shady Sort. "A pleasure, as ever."

You, he barely favours with a glance. He presses a heavy purse into your hand. Small coins stained with salt-water, but together they amount to a tidy sum.

ChildBranches.Name: Drop off the Shady Sort
ChildBranches.Description: She inhales the air, and smiles, perhaps for the first time. "As I remember it," she remarks. "Less mud. More rum."

DefaultEvent.Name: A timely arrival
DefaultEvent.Description: You find your prize-crew loafing sullenly around the Arrant Limpet. You got here just in time. They haven't spent much of your money.

ChildBranches.Name: Collect your ill-gotten gains
ChildBranches.Description: Have you been sending stolen ships to Corsair's Forest?

DefaultEvent.Name: Lies, nonsense, glimmers
DefaultEvent.Description:
Some say she's a Clay Man who freed herself with the power of verse. (Possible.) Others insist she's the personal muse of the King with the Hundred Hearts. (Unlikely.) One claims she zails on a living ship made of the still screaming skulls of her victims. (More sober voices mutter that no, it's just an Alcaeus-class vessel.)

Whatever the truths, few have fought her and survived to tell the tale. Only the bravest of captains risk the lonely parts of the zee where her flag is said to fly.

ChildBranches.Name: Overhear rumours of a Pirate-Poet
ChildBranches.Description: Landlubbers fear pirates. Pirates fear the Poet.

DefaultEvent.Name: Verses amongst iniquity
DefaultEvent.Description: She is halfway through the familiar BAPTISM IN GLASS as you approach, the pirates and corsairs as enraptured by the heavy thumps of verse as are your own crew. She moves on to her most famous work, REMEMBER POLYTHREME, before finally noticing you during THE SCREAM OF CLAY. As the applause and clinking of coins fades, she tilts her head towards the pub door.

ChildBranches.Name: A familiar face
ChildBranches.Description: The Pirate-Poet is here, performing for a crowd outside the Limpet.

DefaultEvent.Name: "Another pebble for the mountain!"
DefaultEvent.Description: He is ambitious, and plans to marry a Princess of the Leopard clan. "How many pearls would be an appropriate offer, do you think? Ten thousand? A hundred? Fathers can be prickly." You take a pair of solacefruit from his trove, their flesh plump and glistening.

ChildBranches.Name: A Gleaming Marauder is assembling an immense hoard of Drowning Pearls
ChildBranches.Description: His teeth are gold; his rings wink with scintillack. A locked box sits beside him, containing delicacies retrieved from the Wisp-Ways. [Trade a Drowning-Pearl for two Solacefruits.]

DefaultEvent.Name: Ravages of time
DefaultEvent.Description: There is no sign of the lad, but it isn't long before someone recognises the description. A huge pirate king, fat with success and with a beard thick enough to catch a bullet roars with laughter. "That old cur! We thought he'd have found his way to the bottom of the sea. The Gant Pole, eh? Good for him! Come! Drink with us, friend. And take a little something from the hold for your trouble."

ChildBranches.Name: Deliver a message from the Gant Pole
ChildBranches.Description:
The request came with a description. A scrawny young lad, still struggling to grow a beard. Someone must have seen him.
 [Have 15 spaces in your cargo hold before choosing this.]

DefaultEvent.Description:
You stand on top a bar, a bitter pint in hand. A few bemused drunkards watch. Who wants to be a hero, you ask, gesturing so your drink sloshes onto a grimy face. Who wants to be a proper d__n hero? 

The zailors' songs die. They all watch, enthralled as you speak of a place fit for the fiercest. Where gigantic mouths bite through hulls and devour ships from inside out. Where leviathans crack ships like eggs, and eat. 

You zailed by such a d__ned ship, but were too afraid to fight the terror below - but these captains - these heroes... Before you even finish, a half dozen have rallied their crews for the docks. They'll sink over Wrack in no time.

ChildBranches.Name: Lure the glory-seekers to Wrack
ChildBranches.Description: You hear the boast echoed up and down the Mourn, resounding from every tavern: I will be the deadliest captain of the zee! Spin them a story of danger.

DefaultEvent.Name: By the evening bell
DefaultEvent.Description:
The Travel-Writer sets across the planks with good speed, his briefcase in his hand. It seems heavy, although he claimed it held only documents and writing equipment for an interview with a pirate king.

The day passes relatively peacefully. There are brawls, but in good fun - the blood washed away with celebratory beer. By night, the boisterous cheer has given way to whispers about an uncommonly brutal murder, executed within an experimental shipyard. They say you couldn't enter the yard without stepping in the victim. 

The Travel-Writer returns. He greets you with a curt nod as he boards your ship.

ChildBranches.Name: Drop off the August Travel-Writer
ChildBranches.Description: "Here is your payment, [q:Addressed As]. I'll be back by the evening bell. We'll discuss my next destination then."

DefaultEvent.Name: An ugly conclusion
DefaultEvent.Description: You never learn who said what, but someone ends up pushed out of a window. It's a long drop out there. The Arrant Limpet trembles dangerously as the brawl gathers momentum.

ChildBranches.Name: An evening at the Arrant Limpet
ChildBranches.Description: A drinking-den by the dock-cradles is a good place for your crew to find companionship and let off steam... but although Gaider's Mourn is a free port, the corsairs prefer their own, and look askance at 'respectable' Londoners.

DefaultEvent.Name: A dislike of spies
DefaultEvent.Description: You and one of your more villainous-looking zailors join a dice-game. (Villainous-looking: but you know for a fact that she tithes to charity and has a delightful singing voice.) The topic turns promisingly to pillage and ambush, but your zailor is a little too forward with her questions. There is a scuffle, and a stabbing. You escape: she does not.

ChildBranches.Name: Gather intelligence
ChildBranches.Description: Gaider's Mourn swarms with pirates, smugglers and captains of uncertain allegiance. You could learn a lot here, but you'll need to go carefully.

DefaultEvent.Name: Nothing to see here
DefaultEvent.Description: Too many questions, and you'll seem suspicious, or a tourist. Too few, and you'll seem either meek or snobbish. You make what inquiries you must. When it's plain the Last Constable isn't here, you depart.  [Check your journal to be reminded of where the Last Constable might be!]

ChildBranches.Name: Search for the Last Constable
ChildBranches.Description: The corsairs aren't welcoming to those who enforce the law. If you're to bring her back unharmed, you'll have to search quietly.
